results.title: For better, for worse
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Many Australian men go to the Philippines in search of a wife as marriage to an Australian is considered an escape from a poverty-stricken future by many Filipinas. This program interviews some of these women and their husbands who live in and around Darwin about their expectations and their lives since. Those interviewed have enjoyed successful marriages, but there are are others who have not been so lucky.

results.title: For all the world to see: a portrait of Professor Fred Hollows (A)
results.creator_credit: Bower Bird Films, ABC-TV (Australia), Pat Fiske and Megan McMurchy
results.brief_description: Fred Hollows was a controversial, larger-than-life character who was abrasive, determined, flamboyant, unconventional and full of contradictions. Some loved him, some hated him. The style of this film, like the man, is direct, forthright, warts and all. Rather than conquer and convert, his philosophy was to train indigenous people to help themselves and this film documents his work in Eritrea, Nepal and here in Australia with the Aborigines. Included is film shot during recent expeditions, archival material and interviews and glimpses of him at home and on the road. “For all the world to see” is bold, wry, intimate and ultimately a very moving tribute to an extraordinary life.

results.title: For all the world's children
results.creator_credit: Warner-Pathe News, UNICEF, Alfred Butterfield and William K McClure
results.brief_description: Portrays the world-wide activities of the United Naitons International Children’s Emergency Fund (UNICEF). Shows all phases of UNICEF’s operations, from the shipment of supplies to child feeding in Europe and the Middle East. Includes sequences on malaria control and anti-tuberculosis vaccination in India. Narrated by Dwight Weist.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Summing up
results.brief_description: Sol Garfunkel concludes the series by summarising some of the practical applications of mathematical discoveries which have been discussed in previous programs. He stresses the importance to all aspects of our lives of mathematics, and the exciting developments in mathematics which have taken place in the last forty years. The most significant of these, of course is the computer - a mathematical idea which is changing the idea of mathematics.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Statistics. 5
results.brief_description: Confident conclusions Inference is the reaching of conclusions from evidence. This program shows how confident a conclusion can be reached with the aid of statistics. The program discusses standard error, confidence intervals, mean quality index and control charts and stresses that all variables must be identified and that all data must be selected, analysed and interpreted very carefully.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Statistics. 4
results.brief_description: Place your bets Gambling relies on chance but a predictable revenue can be earned from gambling by casinos. This program shows how the theory of probability is used to describe patterns in random events. We are shown how to calculate probabilities and how sampling makes deliberate use of randomness, with larger samples decreasing the variability of results. We are then shown standard deviations, the 68 95 99.7 rule and the central limit theorem.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Statistics. 3
results.brief_description: Picture this In this program Sol Garfunkel shows how the immense amount of data which is produced today can be summarised and described using pictorial methods, such as histograms, scatter plots, box plots and 3D pictures produced on computers for data with several variables. He also introduces the language of descriptive statistics - mean, median, range and quartiles. Examples given include baseball batting averages, and sales of soft drinks.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Statistics. 2
results.brief_description: Behind the headlines In this episode Sol Garfunkel looks in greater detail at sampling methods for collecting statistical data. Examples include employment surveys done by the Bureau of Statistics and medical tests on the effect of aspirin on the incidence of heart disease.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Statistics. 1
results.brief_description: Overview Sol Garfunkel introduces us to the science of statistics and the manner in which it permeates our daily lives, from baseball to politics, to medical tests and gambling. The outcome of a single event may be unpredictable, but the outcome of many events is very predictable and this identification of patterns is what statistics is all about. He also introduces ways of collecting data, and in particular how sampling should be done.
